questions.text: Which of the following drugs work as an antagonist of NMDA receptors? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ketamine

 

Ketamine is a well-known NMDA receptor antagonist. It binds to the NMDA receptor, blocking the action of glutamate, an excitatory neurotransmitter. This blockade of NMDA receptors contributes to Ketamine's unique dissociative anesthetic effects, analgesia, and other clinical applications.

 

Mnemonic

 

  • K - Kids: preferred anaesthetic agent in pediatric patients.
  • E - Emergency Reaction: CNS side effects during recovery.
  • T – Thalamocortical junction responsible for dissociative anesthesia, a primary characteristic of ketamine.
  • A - Analgesic. Known as the most potent analgesic among anesthetic agents.
  • M - Meals: Can be administered even with a full stomach, unlike many anesthetics.
  • I - ↑BP/↑IOP/↑ICP: Indicates that ketamine can increase blood pressure (BP), intraocular pressure (IOP), and intracranial pressure (ICP).
  • N - NMDA Antagonist: The primary mechanism of action for ketamine, blocking NMDA receptors which is crucial in its role as an anesthetic.
  • E – Excellent Bronchodilator

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midazolam: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine, a class of drugs that enhance the inhibitory effects of GABA. It does not interact directly with NMDA receptors.

 

Option C. Propofol: Propofol primarily acts by enhancing the activity of GABA receptors. It does not have any significant antagonist action at NMDA receptors.

 

Option D. Thiopentone: Thiopentone is a barbiturate that also works by enhancing GABAergic transmission. It lacks any direct antagonist effect on NMDA receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NMDA Antagonist drugs: (Mnemonic – Kill NMDA Receptors)

 

  • K – Ketamine & S-ketamine
  • N - Nitrous Oxide
  • M - Memantine
  • D - Dextromethorphan
  • A - Amantadine
  • R - Riluzole

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has dual activity against both hepatitis B as well as HIV? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tenofovir


Tenofovir is an antiretroviral medication that has been shown to have dual activity against both HIV and hepatitis B virus (HBV). It is commonly used in the treatment of both infections. Tenofovir works by inhibiting the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is essential for the replication of both viruses, thereby reducing viral load in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abacavir: Abacavir is an antiretroviral drug used primarily for HIV treatment but does not have significant activity against hepatitis B.

 

Option C. Ritonavir: Ritonavir is used to boost the effects of other HIV medications but does not have activity against hepatitis B.

 

Option D. Dolutegravir: Dolutegravir is another antiretroviral used for HIV but lacks significant efficacy against hepatitis B.

 

Educational Objective:


Drug with dual activity against both HIV and hepatitis B: (Mnemonic: LET)

  • Lamivudine
  • Emtricitabine
  • Tenofovir

questions.text: A 22-year-old female seeks advice on an effective post-coital (emergency contraceptive) pill. Which of the following is most suitable for her? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Levonorgestrel

 

Levonorgestrel is a highly effective emergency contraceptive that should be used within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. It works primarily by preventing ovulation or fertilization, depending on the timing of administration. Levonorgestrel is a widely recommended and approved emergency contraceptive due to its safety and efficacy when used correctly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Norethisterone: This is a synthetic progestogen used in various hormonal contraceptives but is not recommended as an emergency contraceptive.

 

Option C. Ethinyl estradiol: This is a synthetic form of estrogen used in combination oral contraceptives, but on its own, it is not suitable as an emergency contraceptive.

 

Option D. Methyl prednisolone: This is a corticosteroid and has no role in emergency contraception. It is used for different medical conditions, such as inflammation and autoimmune diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency contraceptives:

questions.text: A log dose-response curve (DRC) was plotted with isoprenaline alone (black line) and with isoprenaline in the presence of increasing doses of propranolol (red, green and purple lines), as shown below. The graph shows that propranolol is a: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Competitive antagonist

 

Propranolol is identified as a competitive antagonist based on the nature of the dose-response curve (DRC) observed in the graph. When isoprenaline is used alone, it produces a standard dose-response curve. However, when propranolol is introduced, it causes a parallel shift of the dose-response curve to the right. This rightward shift without a change in the maximal response is characteristic of a competitive antagonist. This indicates that propranolol competes with isoprenaline for the same binding site on the beta-1 receptors, thereby inhibiting the action of isoprenaline in a reversible manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Partial agonist: A partial agonist would produce a response but not to the full extent of a full agonist. Propranolol does not produce a response on its own, but instead blocks the response of isoprenaline, which is why it is not a partial agonist.

 

Option B. Agonist: An agonist would produce a biological response by activating the receptor. Propranolol, on the other hand, inhibits the action of an agonist like isoprenaline, hence it is not an agonist.

 

Option D. Non-competitive antagonist: A non-competitive antagonist would reduce the maximal response that the agonist can produce. The graph shows no reduction in the maximal response but rather a shift to the right, which is not consistent with non-competitive antagonism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propranolol is a competitive antagonist of isoprenaline, causing a parallel rightward shift in the dose-response curve without affecting the maximal response.

questions.text: A pathology lab is preparing tissue samples for histological examination. They are using Carnoy's fixative, which contains a specific ratio of methanol to glacial acetic acid (GAA). What is the typical ratio of methanol to glacial acetic acid in Carnoy's fixative?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3:1

 

Carnoys Fixative Composition:

 

The classical Carnoys fixative is a non-aqueous fixative used especially for:

 

  • Cytology
  • Preservation of nucleic acids
  • Fixing glycogen, chromosomes, and lymphoid tissues

 

Typical Composition:

 

  • Absolute ethanol or methanol 3 parts
  • Glacial acetic acid (GAA) 1 part
  • Sometimes chloroform is added in modified versions.

 

So, the typical methanol (or ethanol) to GAA ratio is: 3:1

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6:1: Too high for standard Carnoys fixative

 

Option C. 1:1: Equal parts are not typical for Carnoys fixative

 

Option D. 1:3: Would result in too much acid, not effective for nuclear preservation

questions.text: A 58-year-old hypertensive patient with a history of myocardial infarction (MI) presents with an acute attack of migraine. Which of the following medications should not be given for migraine in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sumatriptan

 

Sumatriptan belongs to a class of drugs called triptans, which are commonly used to treat migraines. Triptans work by constricting blood vessels in the brain, which helps to relieve migraine pain. However, they can also cause vasoconstriction in other parts of the body, including the coronary arteries. This vasoconstriction can potentially trigger coronary artery spasm, reducing blood flow to the heart and worsening the condition of a patient with a history of myocardial infarction (MI).

 

Sumatriptan and ergotamine are commonly used in treating migraine attacks by stimulating 5HT1B1D receptors, which induce vasoconstriction in the brain to alleviate migraine symptoms. While this vasoconstriction is beneficial within the brain, it can have harmful effects elsewhere. Both drugs can cause vasoconstriction in peripheral blood vessels and the coronary artery, potentially leading to serious conditions:

 

  • Peripheral Vasoconstriction: Could result in gangrene, with ergotamine having a higher risk than sumatriptan.
  • Coronary Artery Spasm: This can exacerbate conditions like myocardial infarction (MI).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ibuprofen: Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can be used to manage mild to moderate migraine pain. It does not cause vasoconstriction and is generally safe for patients with a history of MI.

 

Option C. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can be used for migraine prophylaxis (prevention). It does not cause vasoconstriction and can even be beneficial in patients with hypertension, which is a risk factor for both migraine and MI.

 

Option D. Verapamil: Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that can also be used for migraine prophylaxis. It has vasodilatory effects and does not pose a risk of coronary artery spasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triptans, such as sumatriptan & ergotamine, are contraindicated in patients with a history of myocardial infarction or other significant cardiovascular diseases due to their potential to cause coronary artery vasoconstriction

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient, who has been on anti-diabetic therapy for the last 10 years, has experienced three episodes of vaginal Candida infection in the past two months. Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs should be avoided in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Canagliflozin

 

Canagliflozin belongs to the class of drugs called SGLT2 inhibitors. These drugs work by increasing glucose excretion in the urine. While this helps lower blood sugar levels, it also creates an environment in the urogenital tract that is favorable for the growth of yeast like Candida, leading to increased risk of vaginal yeast infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin:  Metformin is a biguanide that works by decreasing glucose production in the liver and improving insulin sensitivity. It does not increase the risk of yeast infections.

 

Option C. Glipizide: Glipizide is a sulfonylurea that stimulates the pancreas to release more insulin. It does not have a direct impact on the urogenital tract or increase the risk of yeast infections.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity. It does not affect glucose levels in the urine and is not associated with an increased risk of yeast infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SGLT2 inhibitors (drugs ending in "-gliflozin" - Canagliflozin, Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin) can increase the risk of urogenital infections, including vaginal candidiasis, due to increased glucose excretion in the urine. They should be used with caution or avoided in patients prone to such infections.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with headache, confusion, visual disturbances, nausea, vomiting, and seizures. On examination, blood pressure is 220/110 mmHg. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for managing his condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IV Labetalol

 

This case presents a hypertensive emergency with signs of hypertensive encephalopathy, as indicated by the symptoms of headache, confusion, visual disturbances, nausea, vomiting, and seizures, along with severely elevated blood pressure (220/110 mmHg). In hypertensive emergencies, the goal is to rapidly reduce blood pressure using intravenous medications to prevent further organ damage.

 

IV Labetalol is a preferred treatment in hypertensive emergencies, especially those involving encephalopathy. Labetalol is a combined alpha and beta-blocker that can reduce blood pressure quickly and effectively, making it ideal for this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral Nifedipine: Oral nifedipine is not appropriate for hypertensive emergencies because it does not act rapidly enough, and oral medications are generally avoided in such acute settings.

 

Option B. Oral Nicardipine capsules: Like oral nifedipine, oral nicardipine is not suitable for emergencies due to its slower onset of action. Nicardipine is more effective in its intravenous form for such cases.

 

Option C. IV Nitroglycerine: Although IV nitroglycerine can be used in hypertensive emergencies, it is not the best choice for hypertensive encephalopathy. Nitroglycerine is more commonly used in cases involving acute coronary syndromes or pulmonary edema, but it is usually avoided in patients with CNS involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DOC for Hypertensive emergencies:

 

  • Encephalopathy - Nicardipine or IV Labetalol

  • Intracranial Hemorrhage - Nicardipine or Labetalol

  • Acute Coronary Syndrome IV Nitroglycerin

  • Pulmonary Edema - Intravenous Nitroglycerin / Sodium Nitroprusside

  • Aortic Dissection Nicardipine in combination with Esmolol or Labetalol

  • In Pregnancy - Labetalol

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred drug for total intravenous anaesthesia? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Propofol

 

Propofol is the preferred drug for total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA) due to several favorable characteristics. It has a rapid onset and offset, allowing for precise control of anesthetic depth. It also has minimal side effects such as nausea and vomiting, making it suitable for day-care surgeries where quick recovery is desired.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketamine: While Ketamine is used for anesthesia, it's primarily known for producing dissociative anesthesia, a state where the patient may appear awake but is disconnected from their surroundings. This makes it less suitable for TIVA compared to Propofol.

 

Option B. Thiopentone: Thiopentone is a barbiturate that was once commonly used for induction of anesthesia. However, its longer duration of action and potential for cardiovascular depression make it less desirable than Propofol for TIVA.

 

Option D. Etomidate: Etomidate is another option for anesthesia induction, especially in patients with cardiovascular concerns due to its minimal impact on the cardiovascular system. However, its association with pain on injection and potential for adrenal suppression limit its use as the primary agent for TIVA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol is the drug of choice for total intravenous anesthesia and day-care surgery due to its rapid onset and offset, and favorable side effect profile.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant female is advised to take folic acid supplements. Folic acid is given in pregnancy to prevent which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neural tube defects

 

Folic acid supplementation during pregnancy is crucial for the prevention of neural tube defects (NTDs), which are serious birth defects of the brain and spine, such as spina bifida and anencephaly. The neural tube forms early in pregnancy, often before a woman knows she is pregnant, which is why folic acid supplementation is recommended even before conception and during early pregnancy.

 

The recommended daily dose of folic acid for most pregnant women is 400 micrograms, but this dose may be increased to 4000 micrograms in women who are at higher risk for NTDs or are taking certain medications, such as anti-epileptic drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia: While folic acid can help prevent anemia due to folate deficiency, the primary reason for its supplementation during pregnancy is to prevent neural tube defects, not anemia.

 

Option C. Preeclampsia: Folic acid is not specifically used to prevent preeclampsia. Other interventions, such as calcium supplementation, are more relevant for preeclampsia prevention.

 

Option D. Gestational diabetes: Folic acid does not play a role in the prevention of gestational diabetes. This condition is managed through diet, exercise, and, if necessary, medication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid supplementation in pregnancy is essential to prevent neural tube defects, with the standard recommended dose being 400 micrograms per day, increased to 4000 micrograms for those at higher risk.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient has just undergone surgery and requires a drug to reverse the muscle relaxation induced during the procedure. Which of the following drugs is used for this purpose? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neostigmine

 

Neostigmine is the correct answer because it is commonly used to reverse the muscle relaxation induced during surgeries. Neostigmine works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, an enzyme responsible for breaking down acetylcholine. By inhibiting this enzyme, neostigmine increases the levels of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, which counteracts the effects of muscle relaxants used during surgery.

 

In clinical practice, neostigmine is often administered alongside atropine. This combination is used to mitigate the cholinergic side effects (such as bradycardia) that can occur due to the increased acetylcholine levels. Atropine, an anticholinergic drug, helps prevent these unwanted side effects by blocking the action of acetylcholine on the heart and other tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bethanechol: Bethanechol is a cholinergic drug used primarily to treat urinary retention and is not used to reverse muscle relaxation induced during surgery.

 

Option B. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug and is used to prevent the side effects of neostigmine rather than to reverse muscle relaxation itself.

 

Option D. Edrophonium: Edrophonium is another acetylcholinesterase inhibitor but is generally used for diagnosing myasthenia gravis rather than reversing muscle relaxation in the surgical setting. Neostigmine is preferred in this context due to its longer duration of action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reversal agents:

 

  • Neostigmine is commonly used to reverse the effects of muscle relaxants after surgery. It works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, increasing acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction, and is combined with atropine to prevent cholinergic side effects.
  • Sugammadex: Known as a Selective Relaxant Binding Agent (SRBA). Specifically used to reverse the effects of Rocuronium and Vecuronium. It is the fastest acting reversal agent and does not cause cholinergic side effects, eliminating the need for atropine.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of rivaroxaban is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Xa inhibitor

 

Rivaroxaban is an oral anticoagulant that works by inhibiting Factor Xa, a crucial enzyme in the blood coagulation cascade. The name "rivaroxaban" itself hints at its mechanism of action, where "Xa" refers to Factor Xa, and "ban" suggests inhibition. By inhibiting Factor Xa, rivaroxaban prevents the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin, thus reducing the formation of fibrin clots. This inhibition is crucial in preventing and treating conditions such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), and reducing the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation.

 

Other Xa blocker drugs: Apixaban, Edoxaban, Betrixaban

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IIa inhibitor: IIa refers to thrombin (Factor IIa), and while inhibiting thrombin is another anticoagulation strategy, rivaroxaban does not act on Factor IIa. Instead, drugs like dabigatran work as direct thrombin inhibitors.

 

Option C. Vitamin K antagonist: This refers to a different class of anticoagulants, such as warfarin, which inhibit the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. Rivaroxaban does not affect vitamin K or its associated pathways.

 

Option D. Antithrombin activation: Antithrombin activation is the mechanism of action for drugs like heparin. Rivaroxaban does not work by activating antithrombin but rather by directly inhibiting Factor Xa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rivaroxaban is a direct, reversible inhibitor of Factor Xa, a key enzyme in the blood coagulation process, and is used as an anticoagulant.

questions.text: A man with diabetes was on medication and forgot to take his meals before going to the gym. During his workout, he collapsed, and his blood sugar level was found to be 50 mg/dL. Which of the following oral antidiabetic drugs can result in hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glimepiride

 

Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea, a class of oral antidiabetic drugs known to stimulate insulin release from pancreatic beta cells. This action can lead to a decrease in blood glucose levels, which, if not balanced with adequate food intake, can result in hypoglycemia. The patient's low blood sugar level (50 mg/dL) and the scenario of collapsing during a workout indicate that hypoglycemia occurred, likely due to the effect of glimepiride.

 

[Mnemonic: any drug which ends with ide can cause hypoglycemia, except glutides (liraglutide), axenatide]

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin: Metformin is a biguanide that primarily decreases hepatic glucose production and increases insulin sensitivity. It does not usually cause hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy because it does not stimulate insulin secretion.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor that increases incretin levels, which in turn increases insulin release and decreases glucagon levels. However, it does not generally cause hypoglycemia as monotherapy because its action is glucose-dependent.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that increases insulin sensitivity but does not stimulate insulin release. Thus, it does not typically cause hypoglycemia when used alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sulfonylureas, like glimepiride, can cause hypoglycemia, especially when meals are skipped, due to their insulin-stimulating effects.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with a high fever, severe headache, confusion, and altered level of consciousness. He has a history of recent travel to a malaria-endemic region. On examination, he is found to have signs of jaundice, anemia, and significant dehydration. His blood pressure is low, and his pulse is rapid and weak. Laboratory tests reveal severe hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. Additionally, his urine output has significantly decreased over the past 24 hours. Blood smears confirm the presence of Plasmodium falciparum. What is the first management step in this situation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intravenous artesunate

 

The patient presents with severe malaria, which is indicated by the clinical symptoms of high fever, altered mental status, jaundice, anemia, and laboratory findings such as thrombocytopenia and hemolytic anemia. Severe malaria is most commonly caused by Plasmodium falciparum, and it requires urgent and aggressive treatment to prevent complications and death.

 

The drug of choice for the treatment of severe malaria, particularly when caused by Plasmodium falciparum, is intravenous (IV) artesunate. Artesunate is highly effective in rapidly reducing the parasitic load, improving symptoms, and decreasing mortality in severe malaria.

 

IV artesunate should be administered for at least 24 to 48 hours, after which the patient can be transitioned to an oral artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) once they are stable and able to tolerate oral medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chloroquine: This option is incorrect. Chloroquine is no longer effective in many regions due to widespread resistance, particularly in Plasmodium falciparum infections. It is not recommended for the treatment of severe malaria.

 

Option C. Artemisinin-based combination therapy: This option is partially correct but not the first step in management. Oral ACT is used as follow-up therapy after the patient has been stabilized with IV artesunate. It is not appropriate as the initial treatment in severe malaria.

 

Option D. Primaquine: This option is incorrect. Primaquine is used for the radical cure of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale infections, where it eliminates hypnozoites from the liver. It is not used in the acute treatment of Plasmodium falciparum or in severe malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In severe malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum, the first-line treatment is intravenous artesunate, which is effective in rapidly reducing parasitemia and improving patient outcomes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with bronchial asthma is currently on inhaler therapy with ipratropium and formoterol. Despite the medication, his symptoms are not improving due to his incoordination of hand and inhaler usage. What should be the next step in management? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Use nebulizer of formoterol and ipratropium

 

The patient's symptoms are not improving due to incoordination between hand use and inhaler operation, which is critical for effective medication delivery. In such cases, the next step is to switch to a nebulizer, which delivers the medication in a mist form that can be inhaled easily without requiring precise coordination between inhalation and device activation. This ensures that the patient receives the full dose of medication effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monitor plasma levels of ipratropium and formoterol: Monitoring plasma levels is not a standard approach in managing asthma symptoms related to inhaler misuse. It would not address the underlying issue of poor coordination.

 

Option C. Use dry powder inhaler of formoterol and ipratropium: A dry powder inhaler also requires good coordination for effective use. Switching to this would not solve the problem of incoordination.

 

Option D. Use budesonide along with formoterol and ipratropium inhaler: Adding budesonide, an anti-inflammatory corticosteroid, might help control inflammation but would not resolve the issue of inhaler incoordination. The primary problem of ineffective drug delivery remains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with bronchial asthma who struggle with the coordination required for using an inhaler, transitioning to a nebulizer is an effective strategy to ensure proper medication delivery and symptom control.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient diagnosed with absence seizures is being treated with ethosuximide. What is the mechanism of action of ethosuximide? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inhibit T-type calcium channels

 

Absence seizures are primarily caused by the overactivity of T-type calcium channels in the thalamic neurons. Ethosuximide is an anticonvulsant drug that specifically works by inhibiting these T-type calcium channels. By blocking these channels, ethosuximide reduces the rhythmic burst firing of thalamic neurons, which is responsible for the generation of the characteristic 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges seen in absence seizures. This action effectively controls and reduces the frequency of absence seizures in affected patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibit sodium channels: This option is incorrect. Inhibition of sodium channels is the mechanism of action for several other anticonvulsants, such as phenytoin, carbamazepine, valproate, and lamotrigine. However, this mechanism does not specifically target the pathophysiology of absence seizures.

 

Option B. GABA transaminase inhibitor: This option is incorrect. Vigabatrin is a drug that works as a GABA transaminase inhibitor, leading to an increase in GABA levels, which is an inhibitory neurotransmitter. This mechanism is not relevant to the treatment of absence seizures.

 

Option C. Inhibit arabinosyl transferase: This option is incorrect. Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase is the mechanism of action for ethambutol, a drug used in the treatment of tuberculosis. This mechanism has no role in the treatment of epilepsy or absence seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethosuximide controls absence seizures by specifically inhibiting T-type calcium channels, reducing the abnormal firing patterns in the thalamus that cause these seizures.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was on metronidazole therapy for a bacterial infection. He attended a party and consumed alcohol. Shortly after, he developed symptoms including intense facial flushing, severe nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, palpitations, and hypotension. What is the likely cause? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Drug interaction

 

The patient experienced a disulfiram-like reaction, which occurs due to the interaction between metronidazole and alcohol. Metronidazole inhibits the enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase, which is responsible for metabolizing acetaldehyde, a byproduct of alcohol metabolism. When this enzyme is inhibited, acetaldehyde accumulates in the body, leading to symptoms such as facial flushing, nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, palpitations, and hypotension. This reaction is similar to what occurs with the drug disulfiram, which is used to deter alcohol consumption in people with alcohol dependence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metronidazole overdose: The symptoms described are not indicative of a metronidazole overdose. Overdose of metronidazole may cause different symptoms, including seizures and peripheral neuropathy, rather than the acute symptoms seen in this scenario.

 

Option B. Methanol poisoning: Methanol poisoning typically presents with symptoms like ataxia, severe sedation, and visual disturbances, which are not mentioned in this case. Methanol poisoning is also more commonly associated with ingestion of methanol, not the combination of alcohol with metronidazole.

 

Option D. Alcohol withdrawal: Alcohol withdrawal is characterized by symptoms such as tremors, agitation, seizures, and hallucinations, none of which are described in this scenario. Additionally, there is no history of alcohol dependence or cessation in the patient, making withdrawal an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metronidazole can cause a disulfiram-like reaction when combined with alcohol, leading to the accumulation of acetaldehyde and subsequent unpleasant symptoms.

questions.text: Anticancer drug that can result in hand and foot syndrome is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Capecitabine

 

Capecitabine is an oral prodrug of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), and both of these drugs are known to cause hand-foot syndrome (palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia). This condition is characterized by redness, swelling, and pain on the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. It occurs due to the leakage of the drug from capillaries in these areas, leading to skin toxicity. Hand-foot syndrome is a well-documented adverse effect of capecitabine, making it the correct answer in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is associated with a different side effect profile, most notably hemorrhagic cystitis, which can be prevented by the administration of mesna.

 

Option B. Bleomycin: Bleomycin is known to cause pulmonary fibrosis and can also result in flagellated pigmentation of the skin.

 

Option C. Paclitaxel: Paclitaxel is an anticancer drug that primarily causes peripheral neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capecitabine & 5FU can cause hand-foot syndrome, which is an important side effect to monitor in patients receiving this treatment.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing treatment for cancer with methotrexate. What is the mechanism of action? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inhibits dihydrofolic acid reductase

 

Methotrexate works by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolic acid reductase (DHFR). DHFR is crucial in converting dihydrofolic acid to tetrahydrofolic acid, a necessary cofactor in DNA synthesis. By blocking DHFR, methotrexate prevents the production of tetrahydrofolic acid, ultimately disrupting DNA synthesis and cell division. This makes it effective against rapidly dividing cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibits DNA gyrase: DNA gyrase is an enzyme involved in DNA replication and repair. While inhibiting it would also disrupt cell division, it is not the primary target of methotrexate.

 

Option B. Inhibits topoisomerase II: Topoisomerase II is another enzyme involved in DNA replication. It is targeted by some anticancer drugs, but not methotrexate.

 

Option D. Alkylates DNA: Alkylating agents work by directly damaging DNA, leading to cell death. Methotrexate does not alkylate DNA; its action is more indirect through inhibiting DHFR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate is an antimetabolite drug that inhibits dihydrofolic acid reductase, an enzyme crucial for DNA synthesis. This mechanism disrupts cell division, making it effective in treating cancer.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man presents to the clinic with a thyroid nodule that he noticed several months ago. He has a family history of thyroid cancer and reports occasional flushing and diarrhea. Laboratory tests show elevated calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the RET proto-oncogene. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the thyroid nodule is performed, and a histopathological image is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

 

Case Summary & Diagnostic Clues:

 

  • 51-year-old man with a thyroid nodule
  • Family history of thyroid cancer
  • Flushing and diarrhea indicates neuroendocrine activity
  • Elevated calcitonin & CEA
  • RET proto-oncogene mutation
  • Histopathology (image shown) supports diagnosis

 

Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC): Key Features

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Papillary thyroid carcinoma: Most common thyroid cancer, but shows Orphan Annie nuclei, nuclear grooves, and is not associated with calcitonin or RET mutation

 

Option B. Follicular thyroid carcinoma: Shows capsular and vascular invasion, not calcitonin elevation or RET mutation

 

Option C. Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma: Very aggressive, occurs in older individuals, and does not produce calcitonin or CEA

 

Key Diagnostic Triad for MTC:

 

  1. Thyroid nodule
  2. Calcitonin & CEA
  3. RET mutation

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with a history of hyperlipidemia was started on statins for elevated triglyceride levels. Despite the statin therapy, his triglyceride levels remain persistently elevated at over 600 mg/dL. Which of the following medications should be administered next to help manage his triglyceride levels? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gemfibrozil

 

Gemfibrozil belongs to the class of drugs known as fibrates. Fibrates are particularly effective in lowering triglyceride levels, which is critical in this patients case given the significantly elevated triglyceride level over 600 mg/dL. This level puts the patient at increased risk of developing pancreatitis, a serious and potentially life-threatening condition. Fibrates, such as gemfibrozil, work by activating peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-alpha (PPAR-alpha), which increases the oxidation of fatty acids and decreases triglyceride levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ezetimibe: This medication works by inhibiting the absorption of cholesterol in the intestines. It is primarily used to lower LDL cholesterol and has a minimal effect on triglyceride levels. It would not be effective in this scenario where significant triglyceride lowering is needed.

 

Option B. Niacin: Niacin, also known as vitamin B3, is effective in increasing HDL cholesterol but is less effective than fibrates in lowering triglycerides. It is not the first choice in managing severe hypertriglyceridemia like in this case.

 

Option D. Evolocumab: Evolocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor used primarily to lower LDL cholesterol, especially in patients with homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia. It is not indicated for the treatment of elevated triglycerides and would not be effective in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with significantly elevated triglyceride levels (over 600 mg/dL) that do not respond adequately to statins, fibrates like gemfibrozil are the next step in management to reduce the risk of pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient undergoing treatment for tuberculosis reports experiencing a decrease in visual acuity and color blindness. Which of the following antitubercular drugs is most likely to cause visual problems? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is an antitubercular drug that is known to cause optic neuritis, which is an inflammation of the optic nerve. This condition can lead to a decrease in visual acuity and color blindness, most notably red-green color blindness.

 

The mnemonic "E for Ethambutol, E for Eye problems" can be used to remember this association.

 

Ethambutol-induced optic neuritis is dose-dependent and can be reversible upon discontinuation of the drug, but if not identified early, it may result in permanent vision loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is associated with hepatotoxicity and peripheral neuropathy, primarily due to its interference with vitamin B6 metabolism.

 

Option B. Rifampicin: Rifampicin can cause orange discoloration of body fluids (urine, sweat, tears) and is a potent enzyme inducer, leading to multiple drug interactions.

 

Option D. Pyrazinamide: Pyrazinamide is known to be hepatotoxic and can cause hyperuricemia, which may lead to gout.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol is an antitubercular drug that can cause optic neuritis, leading to a decrease in visual acuity and red-green color blindness.

questions.text: Identify the provided histological slide:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thymus

 

Identifying features

 

  1. Lobulated architecture
    1. The thymus is divided into numerous lobules by connective tissue septa (trabeculae).
    2. Each lobule has a distinct cortex and medulla.

       
  2. Cortex (Peripheral darker zone)
    1. Darkly stained (basophilic) due to high density of small, immature T lymphocytes (thymocytes).
    2. Contains densely packed lymphocytes with little cytoplasm.
    3. Also contains epithelial reticular cells, but these are harder to identify in the cortex due to the dense lymphocytes.

       
  3. Medulla (Central lighter zone)
    1. Lighter stained (eosinophilic) because it has fewer lymphocytes.
    2. Contains more prominent epithelial reticular cells with pale-staining, larger nuclei.
    3. The medulla of adjacent lobules is continuous, unlike the cortex.

       
  4. Hassalls corpuscles (Hallmark feature!)
    1. Unique identifying feature of thymus.
    2. Found only in the medulla.
    3. Appears as concentrically arranged, eosinophilic (pink) whorls of degenerated epithelial reticular cells with keratinization in the center.

 

Vary in size; can be single or in groups.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Thyroid

 

 

Option C. Spleen

 

 

Option D. Tongue

questions.text:
A 72-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of a sudden onset of severe pain in his right eye, accompanied by blurred vision that started approximately two days ago. He also reports seeing halos around lights and experiencing a significant decrease in visual acuity. His medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus, both of which are well-controlled with medication. He has no prior history of ocular trauma or surgery. On physical examination, the following findings are noted:  

 

  • Visual acuity: Right eye (OD) 20/200, Left eye (OS) 20/40
  • Intraocular pressure (IOP): Right eye (OD) 45 mmHg, Left eye (OS) 16 mmHg
  • Slit-lamp examination:
    • Conjunctival injection in the right eye
    • Corneal edema and a shallow anterior chamber in the right eye
    • A dense, white cataract in the right eye
    • Presence of a significant number of white, particulate matter in the anterior chamber
  • Fundoscopic examination
    • Optic disc and retina details are difficult to visualize in the right eye due to the cataract and corneal edema

 

Laboratory Results

 

Basic blood workup including complete blood count, electrolytes, and blood glucose levels are within normal limits.

 

What is the definitive treatment options for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cataract Surgery

 

The case is of a lens particle glaucoma, happens when the anterior lens capsule gives away due to intumescent cataract, the lens proteins are expelled in the anterior chamber. These proteins cause glaucoma by stopping the aqueous outflow by closing the entry of aqueous to the angle and the trabecular meshwork. The definite treatment of this condition is cataract surgery.

choices.text: Contralateral loss of joint sense and position
Contralateral loss of pain sensation
Ipsilateral loss of complete sensory functions
Contralateral motor functions

questions.text: Which is the characteristic pattern seen in Brown-Sequard syndrome?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Contralateral loss of pain sensation

choices.text: Dry drowning

questions.text: A 45-year-old man was found deceased in his apartment after several days. During the autopsy, the liver appeared as shown in the provided image. Based on these findings, which process affecting the liver is most likely represented in this image?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Putrefaction

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with severe pulmonary hypertension secondary to left-sided heart disease undergoes a surgical procedure that creates a direct communication between the descending aorta and the left pulmonary artery. Which of the following terms is used to describe this surgical shunt, designed to relieve pulmonary hypertension by redirecting blood flow from the systemic circulation to the pulmonary vasculature?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Potts shunt

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with congenital heart defects, characteristic facial anomalies including hypertelorism and low-set ears, and recurrent viral and fungal infections. There is also evidence of hypocalcemia. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.solution: Ans. A) DiGeorge syndrome

choices.text: Morning peak of plasma cortisol level
Release of cortisol in response to stress
Sodium retention in response to hypovolemia
Synthesis if adrenal sex steroids

questions.text: A patient has neurosurgery for a pituitary tumor that requires resection of the gland. Which of the following functions of the adrenal gland will be preserved postoperatively?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Sodium retention in response to hypovolemia

choices.text: Transposition of the great vessels

questions.text: A senior cardiologist discusses a congenital heart defect with residents, focusing on a developmental anomaly due to anterior displacement of the cono-truncal septum, which causes an unequal division of the conus cordis. Which condition is associated with this defect?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Tetralogy of Fallot
